page.title: 02LAND USE, SOUTH MENDIP HILLS
page.content: Main present day land use of the land is in large measure a response to very varied physical conditions. From the warmer south facing footslope with its well drained brown earth soils to the colder, wetter and more exposed plateau with thinner soils developed on{carboniferous limestone.}Land use varies from intensive fruit, vegetable and flower growing to more extensive forms on the plateau. Important deciduous woods exist on the steep slope (Stoke Woods) and the influence of physical conditions is manifest in the use of{dolomitic conglomerate stone in the village and the existence of an important limestone quarry (Westbury Quarry) in square 5050. The plateau is characterised by frequent rocky outcrops and much of the land is covered by scrub vegetation.
